I.  INTRODUCTION
1. During the 2001 Country Programming Mission, the Government of India requested
technical assistance (TA) from the Asian Development Bank (ADB) to prepare the Madhya
Pradesh State Road Sector Development Project which is included in the 2002-2004 lending
program for India. The TA Fact-Finding Mission visited India from 19 to 23 June 2001 and
reached an understanding with the Government on the scope and other aspects of the TA.1
II.  BACKGROUND AND RATIONALE
2. ADB has taken a focal state approach for its state-level interventions giving high
priority to the sound management of public finance, a prerequisite for sustainable investment
interventions in a state. Gujarat was the first state selected as a focal state, and Madhya
Pradesh (MP) the second. An essential element of the focal state approach is sequencing of
interventions, starting from a public resource management program loan and moving to
individual sector loans, such as those in the power and road sectors. The proposed road
sector development project forms part of this sequential approach.
3. Statewide Enterprise Reform Efforts Under a Program Loan. With per capita
income at less than $200 per year, MP is among the poorest states in India. MP’s industrial
base is still predominantly agricultural; manufacturing and service sectors lag behind.2 MP’s
weak revenue base has been a major problem. In 1999 the fiscal deficit reached 5.4 percent
of the gross state domestic product.  To address this problem, ADB agreed to extend a $250
million loan to MP in December 1999 to help implement a public resource management
program; a major aspect was the restructuring of public sector undertakings. As part of its
restructuring efforts, the Madhya Pradesh government (MPG) has taken a series of actions
including: (i) introducing a voluntary retirement scheme designed to minimize the economic
impact of downsizing or closure of public sector undertakings, and (ii) instituting social safety
net programs to help displaced staff and workers reenter the labor markets. The proposed
restructuring of the Public Works Department (PWD) is in line with the overall reform efforts
for public sector undertakings.
4. Road Sector.  MP has 67,205 kilometers (km) of roads, consisting of 4,717 km of
national highways, 7,459 km of state highways, 31,660 km of major district roads, and
255,033 km of rural roads.3 MP’s road sector has long suffered from a chronic shortage of
funds. This has resulted in premature deterioration of the road network. Many parts of state
roads and major district roads have deteriorated to the point of needing the existing roads to
be rebuilt from the subbase to the pavement (i.e., full rehabilitation).
5. Faced with this situation, the MPG has decided to launch a rapid rehabilitation and
upgrading program for state roads. From its entire network, MPG has chosen 14 corridors
totaling 1,961 km as “high density corridors.” Rehabilitation of these will be carried out
through a new arrangement with maximum participation of the private sector. The new
arrangement includes the following main features:

(i)  The State Bridge Construction Corporation (SBCC) was revived, after its
closure in 1993, as an implementing agency. Staffed with a small number of
newly assigned professional staff (approximately 20), SBCC will carry out its
entire role by contracting out to the private sector.
(ii)  Private sector entities will be competitively selected and award will be to the
one  with  the  lowest  grant  amount  from  the  MPG.  Concessionaires  will
rehabilitate and operate roads for 15 years and then transfer them to MPG.
(iii)  Necessary  funds  for  these  grants  will  be  mobilized  through  bonds  to  be
issued by the Infrastructure Investment Fund Board, created in early 2001.
6. This  scheme  has  functioned  well.  Being  operationalized  only  in  February  2001,
SBCC has already selected rehabilitate, operate, and transfer concessionaires for the first
seven corridors. The second group of concessionaires will be selected by the end of October
2001 for four corridors.  The relative success of the public-private partnership scheme in MP
points to the importance of considering some critical elements to be taken into account for
future MP reforms:
(i)  If adequately funded and efficiently organized, a small-sized implementation
agency can deliver substantial road construction works in a relatively short
period of time in MP.
(ii)  If appropriately designed and underpinned by a proper level of public sector
support, the state road subsector could attract a significant level of private
sector participation.
(iii)  The MPG has adequate institutional capability to carry out complicated and
innovative reforms.
7. Given this background, the TA Fact-Finding Mission and the MPG agreed to address
an even more difficult task, i.e., PWD restructuring, in the TA and ensuing project.
8. Need to Restructure PWD. The PWD system has existed for more than a century
without being subjected to any major organizational changes. India introduced the PWD
system in all states in the mid-1850s with similarly mandated functions. Delivering all road-
related services (including design, construction, operation, and maintenance) by its own
cadre of engineers and labor has been the PWD core function. It was an efficient system a
century ago under the force account system, but not now when most of the road works are
contracted out to the private sector. Typical problems facing PWDs include underfunding,
overstaffing, and delayed delivery of road rehabilitation and maintenance services. State
governments  understand  the  problems,  but  they  have  taken  little  action  because  of
difficulties likely to be encountered in restructuring the PWDs. Successful PWD reform in
one state would have a significant demonstration effect for the others.
9. While  the  various  PWDs  experience  similar  problems,  the  seriousness  of  the
problems differs from state to state. The situation in MP is among the most difficult in India,
with road conditions generally poorer than those in neighboring states. This is largely due to
the insufficient budgetary allocation for road maintenance. In 2000, MP spent Rs22,500 per
km, which is only one fourth of that of Andhra Pradesh. The number of employees of MP’s
PWD exceeds 50,000. Salaries and wages spent for the employees account for about 50
percent of the budgetary allocation to PWD (2000/01 nonplan allocation to PWD).

3
10. Cognizant  of  these  problems,  PWD  has  decided  to  launch  an  institutional
development study for MP to be completed by an international consulting firm.4 In July 2001,
the  consultant  developed  a  broad-based  strategy,  following  international  best  practices.
However, the strategy did not adequately address a fundamental issue associated with state
road management, i.e., inefficiency and overstaffing of PWD.
11. In June 2001, ADB’s TA Fact-Finding Mission visited MP and discussed state road
management issues with the MPG. The Mission has reached an agreement with the MPG to
address the organizational issue in the TA and in the proposed Project. Essential elements
to be considered in this restructuring exercise are as follows:
(i)  Separation of regulatory and operational functions: The current PWD
covers both aspects under its responsibilities, but these two functions have to
be separated. A possible approach would be to transform the PWD into (i) a
highway authority to focus on regulations, policy formulation, and planning
aspects; and (ii) an implementing agency, similar to SBCC, that would be
responsible  for  delivering  road  upgrading  and  maintenance  programs  by
contracting out.
(ii)  Empowerment of implementing agencies. Implementation agencies should
be given adequate funds and decision-making authority so that they can
deliver their services in an efficient manner. A road fund or other similarly
designed funding mechanism will be established for this purpose.
(iii)  Minimization  of  adverse  impact  of  PWD  restructuring.  The smooth
implementation of social safety net programs including a voluntary retirement
scheme  is  critically  important  to  facilitate  the  transition  of  employees;
adequate support must be provided to redundant PWD employees wishing to
establish construction and maintenance companies.
12. Recently, PWD formulated a new road sector development policy,5 emphasizing the
need  to  (i)  upgrade  the  existing  road  networks;  (ii)  strengthen  road  maintenance  by
establishing  a  road  maintenance  fund  and  developing  a  computer-based  pavement
management system; (iii) enhance the level of technology for highway construction and
maintenance,  and  develop  human  resources  for  this;  and  (iv)  facilitate  private  sector
participation in road rehabilitation and maintenance. The new policy highlights the need for
radical changes in the existing system.
13. With these new developments, the reform agenda can now be consolidated and an
integrated plan needs to be developed with a clear focus on the fundamental issues. The
action should be followed later by a series of consultations with a broad range of key
stakeholders  including  those  directly  affected  by  plan  implementation,  legislature,  road
users, construction industries, and relevant nongovernment organizations.
14. Concept  for  the  MP  State  Road  Sector  Development  Project.  The  primary
objective of the ensuing Project will be to establish an institutional arrangement to deliver
state road development and maintenance services in an efficient and transparent manner.
This  will  require  development  and  implementation  of  a  series  of  plans  and  strategies.
Another and equally important project objective is to remove capacity bottlenecks of the
existing road networks. The MPG has identified several high priority corridors which would

III. THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
A. Objective
15. The main purpose of the TA is to help the MPG prepare a sector development
program for reengineering6 the state road management system by developing necessary
reform and implementation plans. The TA will also assist the MPG in preparing investment
components for state road rehabilitation and upgrading.
B. Scope
16. The TA will have four components.
17. Component A. Develop, as part of the systemwide reform exercises under the
programmatic approach for India’s highway sector, an overall plan for policy and institutional
reforms of the state road subsector in India.
18. Component B. Develop for MP (i) an overall plan for reengineering the state road
management system, (ii) a transition plan for PWD from the existing organization to a
reengineered  structure,  and  (iii)  a  social  marketing  strategy  identifying  major  target
audiences or key stakeholders and developing public campaign strategies.
19. Component C. Develop (i) an overall financing strategy for the development of
state roads, and (ii) a plan for establishing a road fund to develop and maintain state roads
and major district roads of MP.
20. Component D. Provide support to PWD of MP for preparing the ensuing project,
covering (i) environmental and social assessment, (ii) economic and financial analysis, and
(iii) preliminary engineering design and procurement support.  Prepare the logical framework
for that project.
C. Cost Estimates and Financing Plan
21. The total cost of the TA is estimated at $800,000 equivalent, consisting of $545,946
in  foreign  exchange  and  $254,054  equivalent  in  local  currency  cost.  ADB  will  finance
$600,000 equivalent from the ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund covering the full
foreign  exchange  cost  and  $54,054  of  the  local  currency  cost.  The  MPG  will  finance
$200,000 equivalent by providing office accommodation, support facilities, counterpart staff,
vehicles, and other logistical support. The detailed cost estimates are in Appendix 1.

D. Implementation Arrangements
22.  PWD will be the Executing Agency and will establish a project preparation unit
headed by a chief engineer consisting of several full-time and part-time professional staff. A
high-level steering committee will provide overall guidance to the unit, and comprise the
minister (PWD) as chair, and representatives of the Finance Department, Law Department,
PWD, SBCC, Infrastructure Investment Fund Board, chambers of commerce, road transport
industries, and nongovernment organizations representing the interest of road users.
23. The TA consultants will be recruited by ADB in accordance with its Guidelines on the
Use of Consultants and other arrangements satisfactory to ADB for the engagement of
domestic consultants. Specific methods of engaging consultants will differ from component
to component. For component A, individual consultants will be engaged. For components B,
C and D, consulting firms will be engaged in accordance with simplified technical proposal
selection procedures.
24. Terms of reference for the consultants are outlined in Appendix 2.(cid:1)The consultants,
both individual and a firm, are expected to commence their services in December 2001 and
finish by August 2002.
IV. THE PRESIDENT’S DECISION
25. The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the
provision of technical assistance to the Government of India in an amount not exceeding the
equivalent of $600,000 for the purpose of preparing the Madhya Pradesh State Road Sector
Development Project, and hereby reports such action to the Board. The technical assistance
will be financed initially as a grant, but will be subject to the reimbursement arrangements
set forth in the Board papers on Technical Assistance Operations (Doc. R51-77, dated 20
May 1977) and Streamlining of Technical Assistance Operations (Doc. R44-88, dated 21
March 1988), including the provision that, in the event of the technical assistance resulting in
a loan from ADB, ADB may charge against such loan, and recover from it, the portion of the
initial grant that exceeds $250,000 equivalent.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTING SERVICES
A.  Component A
1. A team of individual consultants, one international and one domestic, will be engaged
because the activities need to coincide with ADB’s missions, which will conduct extensive policy
dialogue with the Madhya Pradesh (MP) Government. The international consultant, a transport
economist-specialist (1.4 person-months), must have extensive knowledge of transport sector
policies and institutional reforms. The domestic consultant (1.4 person-months), needs to have
extensive knowledge on India’s transport sector. Activities include the following:
(i)  Review the existing reports and documents dealing with policy and institutional
reforms of India’s highway sector including the documentation for the Western
Transport Corridor Project and World Bank’s Project Appraisal Document for the
Institutional  Development  Study  Technical  Assistance  Loan,  and  Institutional
Development Study for Madhya Pradesh Public Works Department (PWD).
(ii)  Prepare a note providing an overview of the state road subsector in India and
also for MP, including an analysis of overall performance and issues, together
with recommendations for future improvement (Technical Report A-1 on the
sector overview).
(iii)  Develop overall plans for policy and institutional reforms of the state road sub-
sector for India and for MP respectively (Technical Report A-2 on a policy and
institutional reform road map).
(iv)  Develop  a  logical  framework  for  the  proposed  MP  State  Road  Sector
Development Project (Technical Report A-3 on the logical framework of the
Project).
B.  Components B and C
2. A consulting firm will be contracted.  While each task requires a number of specialists as
listed in subsequent paras., they are not necessarily different persons; one specialist could
cover two to three areas if s/he have necessary qualifications and expertise. Among the various
experts, one will be assigned as a tasks manager who will oversee all tasks and make sure that
all activities are carried out in a coordinated and timely manner, in addition to the specific task
assigned. The technical proposal to be submitted by the consultants should elaborate how the
entire team is formed and managed.
1. Component B: Reengineering the MP State Road Management System
3. The team consisting of 5.1 person-months of international consultants and 1.4 person-
months of domestic consultants comprises (i) a transport economist-specialist (international)
who is familiar with the organizational restructuring of government agencies and state-owned
enterprises; (ii) a specialist (international) who is familiar with wages and welfare structures,
including severance packages, and social safety nets, including voluntary retirement schemes;
(iii) a specialist for public relations (international) who is familiar with public relations campaign
strategies;  and  (iv)  a  legal  expert  (domestic)  who  is  familiar  with  corporate  law  and  has
extensive experience in assisting clients to establish a company in India. Activities include the
following:

C. Reporting Requirements
10. The consultants will submit four copies of the reports/notes to the Asian Development
Bank (ADB) and 16 copies to the MP government.  The timetable for the submission of the
reports is as follows:
(i)  an inception report, setting out the detailed work schedule and plan including the
date  of  the  submission  of  technical  reports,  within  three  weeks  of
commencement of the consulting services;
(ii)  technical reports to be submitted by the time set out in the inception report and
